alternatives.transcript: this is NBC for you are watching Washington's most watched News live this is news for today

good morning and welcome to Viewpoint the battle over tobacco took a decided turn two weeks ago when the Liggett group of tobacco manufacturer broke ranks with the other manufacturers and in effect publicly admitted that smoking is addictive and that smoking can cause cancer it was really the first chink and what had been an ironclad front by the tobacco companies are question today on Viewpoint is what does it mean for the future of tobacco the future of the tobacco industry in the direction of the debate

this country right now and with us to discuss these issues are Thomas Lauria who is assistant to the president of the tobacco Institute and William Novelli president of the campaign for tobacco-free kids thank you both for joining us this morning it's a pleasure to have you here mr. Lorry ask you first to what does it mean for the future of tobacco this Liggett decision well I think that mr. LeBeau from Liggett spoke for himself as all of us have a right to express our opinion he expressed his we

we don't think that he spoke on behalf of the industry or for all the industry he spoke for Bennett Lebow mr. Novelli not quite I think that the Liggett decision or the Liggett settlement is going to be huge because For the First Time here we have a member of the club a member of the inner circle of the tobacco industry speaking out and admitting as you say that the product is addictive and causes disease but he also admitted something else which is that the tobacco companies Target children

and so in addition to that having handed over all those documents and then made his Executives available for Testimony there were going to be there I think will be very very large repercussions coming out of this mystery how about that well again he can express his opinion he cannot speak to the other companies he can say what he thinks about them but he certainly is an authorized to discuss something from Lowe's or r.j. Reynolds or Philip Morris and he just doesn't know anything about those companies but it but it is a fact

that until this time the tobacco companies had presented a united front because everything right but there were there were United facts which link the companies together and we believe that in an appropriate court of law when there's information is discussed or we will be found to be not doing the things that were accused of doing

I'm not understand sure that I understand that logic they have admitted and in fact as we said that smoking causes cancer and that it is addictive this is the first time it's ever been said by a tobacco company they publicly admitted that they are a manufacturer it's coming from the horse's mouth well mr. LeBeau as the corporate Raider who recently took over leg it and in fact is now a negotiating to bankrupt it as I said is entitled as a

and just say whatever he wants about anything we all are whether or not he or anyone else can can validate the things that he said is another story but with this opens the floodgates that's what I'm saying and well I think the flood gates have been opened for quite a while I mean we have found that tobacco companies have been under the cloud of litigation since not almost continuously since 1957 and obviously with what we Face we will continue to be but we don't see this as a particular new Floodgate just a continuation of something that's been

in the courts a long time but you've never faced the huge financial windfall that this will entail because you've never admitted that smoking causes cancer or that smoking is addictive if you were to admit that it would in fact open the financial floodgates to lawsuits now those gates are opened right well I'm not a lawyer and I think that the industries positions that as long as I've been with them have been to recognize and acknowledge

that smoking has been linked as a risk factor for many important health problems I think that we as a society have known that hundreds of years we have Society of address to that specifically through legislation with warning labels and all that for over 30 years and the granddaddy of all warning labels is about as well known as any warning label could be and I think that with the

current climate we're seeing a lot of headlines I'm a daily basis obviously but fundamentally nothing has changed to alter historical fact and struggle president has anything changed mr. Kelly well I think is mr. Lorry said this is part of a Continuum but we see it as a major major step what's going to happen here we believe is that this will have an impact on a lot of different kinds of litigation all those documents that are going to be reviewed and hopefully release to the turn

General will have an impact on those suits there will be individual plaintiff suits there are class action suits so in the courts this will this we believe will make a difference then there's the issue of Regulation we think this will have some impact there for example the FTC is now considering whether to reopen its investigation of whether Joe Camel is a device aimed at children but then there's something else that's important and that is that this is having an impact in the court of public opinion

in surveys are showing that the public which has traditionally held tobacco companies and low regard is holding them in even lower repute at this point than ever before and we don't think that legislators can long withstand the kind of public opinion that's going to come about you mentioned a Joe Camel and it brings to mind an article that I read fairly recently in a magazine called American demographics the article was written by a black businessman who complained about how to few American companies

we target the inner city specifically Target the black demographic and he said to few American corporations fail to realize that we are an important buying segments of the marketplace we are ignored the tobacco companies have done precisely that they've done exactly what any good businessman would want to do and now they're being trashed for it well I doubt that the author of that article had in mind targeting black kids with tobacco he probably meant with positive Goods

well that's a subjective opinion though isn't it well I don't have a choice whether or not we want to smell I give you an example just recently camel came out with a menthol brand extension and as a result of this there's a network of black clergy around the country which are trying to get camel to withdraw the Menthol because they realize that eighty percent of all black Smokers smoke menthol cigarettes including black kids that smoking among African-American children is going up so this is the kind of reaction you get when the target when the targeting is tobacco and not

on some useful products Lori which weren't tobacco companies doing in this case precisely what any good businessman would do well there are 450 Brandon brand extensions and there was nothing specific to the candle campaign except the predilection among some black smokers prefer Menthol there was no there was no like percent don't 80% of black smokers performance also they have hundreds of Menthol choices this is not a this is not anything specifically directed at any particular community

una T it's really expanding our brand the brand extension black kids fortunately smoke much less than white kids white kids smoke at a level that we consider to be too high but black smoke less than that Hispanic smoke less than that Asian smoke even less than that there are just different demographic plateaus for kids smoking all of them are too high I think that's why the industry has had so many programs in place since 63 to try to curb that this is not youth smoking is not a
shoe for us it's one that we have addressed for longer than we have had warning labels on our path on that note we'll take a short break we'll continue our discussion about tobacco right after this

good morning and welcome back to view point we're talking about the future of tobacco in the aftermath of the ligand groups decision to publicly admit that cigarettes cause cancer and that they are addictive mr. Novelli a lot of people have suggested that this will again open the floodgates I said but perhaps an unintended ways for instance lots of things can be perceived of as unhealthy lots of things can cause premature death Hostess Twinkies if you eat enough of them meet liquor automobiles

pajamas you name it all of these things are potentially unhealthy what's to prevent a flood of lawsuits against these products well the tobacco industry has actually used that argument you know today tobacco tomorrow I fed doughnuts I mean that kind of a slippery slope argument is really suspicious and the reason for this is that there is no other product like tobacco if you go to the problem which is what you have to begin with we're talking about well over 400,000

Americans a year dying from tobacco-related disease there is nothing like that in any other product category in America not AIDS not accidents not fires nothing else to make a case for ended up for heart disease though I think no but don't that diets and heart disease which is the leading call the leading killer of people in the United States well the people who die from heart disease most of them are a good portion of them actually die from tobacco-related heart disease but the point you're making that that other products can cause disease of course

products used in moderation will not cause disease whereas tobacco used as directed causes disease and death it will kill you so the slippery slope argument really isn't one that ought to be pursued it should be pursued quite vigorously liquid what is happening with alcohol no sooner had President Clinton just last week talked about curbing potential liquor ads when Mothers Against Drunk Driving and others clamored we must also address beer and wine ads in both

print and on television that seems a slippery slope a legal precedent set for one thing such as what the FDA is trying to do to regulate tobacco advertisements can be applied directly because of the regulatory precedent established to anything else any other group wants that's why we have a First Amendment that's what the first amendment is sacrosanct and so important and that is also the big one of the basis for our litigation against the FDA is because you cannot by decree just eliminate the right of any

any or any person to communicate with a customer base and that's what I think we're talking about when we mention a slippery slope more about the legal technicalities of what can spring from that mr. Vela is there anybody left on the planet who does not know and has not known for decades that cigarettes are dangerous probably most people know but the problem is that tobacco is addictive and the average smoker in this country becomes a regular smoker at age 14 so

knowledge is not always going to change Behavior what we have here is an addictive product hooks kids before they can make rational adult decisions you go into adulthood and you have huge percentages of people who cannot quit who try many times and failed to quit so here again is an argument that gets knocked down the argument of a free adult decision these are children making decisions addictive products that go on into adulthood why have people been able to stop that many people have been able to stop and there are many

on the market that can help people to stop many people have not been able to stop despite every effort they've made my father was a 2 pack a day smoker Chesterfields when the surgeon general's report came out in 1964 he quit and so he believes that anybody can quit but it's not true that anybody can quit there are many people who are not able to and of course what we're talking about is kids beginning before they can figure out what's going on maybe those people don't have enough willpower that may be true that's not the point

point the point is we have an addictive product that kills people that begins with children and the most chilling statistic of all is the one that just came out from the CDC and which they project that 5 million teenagers who are alive today these are our kids are going to die prematurely from tobacco disease unless we turn this thing around there's an expression be careful for what you wish for because your wish may be granted I'm reminded of an incident just this past week where a study came fourth in regard to the television rating system

one group found that was having precisely surprise surprise the opposite effect that you know PG-13 or adulterated material was drawing youngsters and teenagers to watch might this also be an unintended consequence of reducing tobacco advertising well it is in a way a problem this idea of forbidden fruit and the tobacco industry actually contributes to this because what they say to kids is this is an adult activity this is not for you IE if you want to be a grown-up this is the

thing to do and so what we really need to do is we really need to help adults quit as well as tell kids not to begin because we don't want them to think this is an adult behavior that you should emulate mr. Lorry I'll give you a chance to respond I heard you sighing during his remarks but we need to take a break right now we'll continue our discussion on Viewpoint right after this

welcome back to Viewpoint Tom Laurie of the tobacco Institute I'm curious what your thoughts are about this Aura of forbidden fruit if tobacco advertising were to be limited in some way their accusation is often made that it is the tobacco industry that is establishing tobacco as an adult product to get kids to enjoy forbidden fruit when in fact it's the law in all 50 states that it's an adult product that's beyond contention the fact that that our government the federal and state level have proclaimed it's such

makes it an adult product it's not because of tobacco advertising when you can you can blame us for everything including Cyclones but the fact remains that there's certain adult Behavior that's hedonistic Lee driven teenagers are inordinately curious they get each other to start smoking there is a an enormous peer pressure on kids not only to smoke and to drink and to have sex and take drugs and do lots of things we don't want them to do but that is not coming from commercial Enterprises that is come that pressure is coming from each other from old

her siblings from lacks a days ago parents or from just adolescent curiosity and with all the clamor about tobacco very little is talked about in terms of addressing why kids smoke is the things that we can do as parents things that we can do as a society to help alleviate that peer pressure to help mitigate it through communication skills and that is such an important key that is missing in the formula on how to get kids not to start smoking if anti-smoking groups spent a fraction of the time they spend on on addressing real

why kids smoke the even the fda's own focus groups of teens priors of promulgating the regulation the FDA themselves knows that kids smoke for reasons that have nothing to do with advertising non-smoking teens are not walk by a billboard in suddenly decide to start smoking but the persuasion of their friends goes a long way there is some forbidden fruit in it the more the more kids are told not to do with the more they are tempted to do it but nonetheless that's nonetheless as a reason enough to stop them at the sales counter that's why the tobacco industry's efforts the we card program

and other programs before that were meant to help retailers stop the sale in the first place since we are good at marketing and retailing we believe that's where we can do the most good but if we think the campaign for tobacco-free kids would would endorse a program to help parents with peer pressure they'd probably get lowered teen smoking rates how about that peer pressure it's true that there are a lot of complex reasons why kids smoke pure pressures one adult role modeling is another there are lots of reasons one of the reasons though is tobacco industry marketing

there is good evidence that that industry marketing has an effect on kids experimentation and also their brand Preference they spend five billion dollars a year on this marketing this is the equivalent of saturation bombing we have got to get that down so that a teacher a parent can have a chance to counsel a child and to make a difference there are those who have suggested that if you really want to stop children from smoking you need to hit them where it hurts in the pocketbook by making cigarettes more and more expensive and I believe

that anti-tobacco forces are pushing according to an article I read in today's New York Times for a combination of state and federal tax increases that could raise the cost of a pack of cigarettes by more than a dollar isn't that the proper approach if you want to stop kids from smoking yes price increases are one of the key aspects of a comprehensive program getting priced up we'll get consumption down especially among children but that's not the only thing although it's very important and we're very active in all the states trying to help help to make this come about

out but if you can combine tax increases with reduce tobacco marketing with good public education keep working on environmental tobacco smoke and also really work at the retail counter to make tobacco unavailable to children get it behind the counter make it unavailable to kids who are under age if you put all that together including the tax part then you will have a program that will work what is the tobacco institute's opinion of higher taxes that they will induce crossbow

sales can either be States going to go along with it they are engraved invitation for a black market and most importantly the among the 46 million adults who smoke that impacts especially with lower income people very directly on their take-home pay and they have made a decision just to smoke they should not be punished with the tax code that others don't have to pay it seems regressive to go back and hit lower income people that hard but also we never designed the tax code to be

a punitive it's not a punishment is a method for raising revenues and if you can tax tobacco to Extinction you can tax alcohol you could tax anything you want but we don't do it that way we have a fair tax policy levels the burden among all segments of society and all product can you respond to that in 10 seconds we got to take a break I think there are two things that the tobacco industry fears most one is increased taxes and the other is real regulation and I think if we got both those things into place it would make a big difference we'll take a short break

change Behavior education is one legislation is a part as I said earlier got well the education thing there despite what you say I don't think there's anybody on the planet who does not know the smoking is unhealthy and that that it causes cancer I'm not just talking about telling people that cigarettes cause cancer I mean that's part of it but one of the good things that research in Massachusetts and California and other states have shown is that if you are able to convince kids that the cigarette companies the tobacco industry

is out to manipulate them to really fool them into smoking but this does have an effect this is a good enough That's the basis of capitalism itself is to fool people to get them to buy your product right this we're talking about a product here that kills people that addicts children there can't be anybody in the country who wants kids to smoke the tobacco industry claims it doesn't want kids to smoke we've got a lot of data among smokers who say we don't want children to smoke we've got to do something about this and to sit back and say you can't legislate change is really

not to the way to bring about good change I think we can make a big difference the ligand group has admitted that it targeted children isn't that the proverbial pardon the expression Smoking Gun here I don't think so if you read press accounts Liggett in phatak Lee says they didn't they just been in limbo things others do their very very cautious about that point and it's often misreported I think that as the events unfold and that's looked into that will be even more obvious in the minute or so

just like this and we're going to have to take this fight Global down Laura and ten years down the road ten years down the road I think things will be very much the same I think some of the unfortunately some of the litigation we see will still not be settled if it continues down this path I think you'll probably see in a gradual decline in smoking because it's been happening since 1964 anyway I think that that things would probably be more like they are now than people have suspect Tamil oriya from the tobacco Institute William Novelli from the campaign for tobacco-free kids we appreciate
